page.title: 01Fair Head
page.content: The stepped cliffs of limestone and basalt which make up the headland are among the foremost scenic attractions of northern County Antrim, a particul- arly fine view being from Bally castle across the bay. Linked to the A2 road only by narrow lanes, the small farms are exposed and poor, keeping only a few cattle and sheep on the wet rough grazings. The fields are infested with rushes and boggy and are bounded by boulder and turf banks, topped with rickety barbed wire fences. The area is rich in historical sites including an Iron Age fort (Doonmore) and a crannog, or artificial lake island, while a prehistoric tomb lies on the western slope of Crockanore. The eastern shore is a Nature Reserve owned by the National Trust.
